title: preston-athletic-players-swap-boots-bicycles-fundraiser
story: Members of Preston Athletic FCrsquos squad got on their bikes to raise money for the club and the NHS on Saturday, August .A dozen players, as a relay team, cycled from Dunbar Unitedrsquos New Countess Park through East Lothian, Midlothian and Edinburgh before reaching the finish line at their home ground, the Pennypit.Kai Austin was among those setting off from the Seasidersrsquo ground at about am but had to make a quick substitution before kick-off.He said: ldquoI had not checked my bike for about a week beforehand.ldquoI was putting it into the car and noticed the back tyre was flat.ldquoI thought we would pump it up when we got there.ldquoAfter we arrived, my girlfriend drove away and I was walking along and noticed the tyre was flat again.Fortunately, one of Kairsquos team-mates for the cycle had a spare bike and they were quickly able to get on the open road.The fundraiser came about with players deciding to visit  football grounds ndash the home of  teams ndash ahead of the   season.The first stop was at Millfield , before going on to Foresters Parkand New Recreation Park .The second group of cyclists ventured into Midlothian and ticked off Kingrsquos Park , Newbattle Complex , New Victoria Park , Newbyres Park , New Dundas Parkand Ferguson Park .Nathan Stokes, who plays in midfield and up front, was among the third group, who completed the Midlothian section by travelling on to Penicuik Park .Then it was into the Capital and Paties Road , Meggetland , Saughton Enclosureand Christie Gillies Park .Finally, the Edinburgh section was complete with a visit to Ainslie Park Stadium , St Marks Parkand Peffermillbefore ing to East Lothian and Olivebankand the Pennypit.Nathan, , said: ldquoTo get to Peffermill, we came down Cameron Toll.ldquoFrom the Commonwealth Pool, it is all downhill and by that point my legs were screaming.ldquoFor me, it was a nice relaxing run down there and when we reached Peffermill we knew it was only  minutes to Musselburgh and then another - minutes to the Pans. Getting to East Lothian was definitely a psychological boost.The cyclists finished at the Pennypit shortly after pm, where they were met by the participants from the earlier legs.Right-back Kai, who lives just metres from the ground in Prestonpans, was among those at the finish line. He said: ldquoWe had the people that did the cycle and some people there that were not able to do it because of injury.ldquoThe club put on a socially distanced get-together and put on some sausage rolls and pies.ldquoWe were sitting in the stand and were there for them arriving and cheered them in.Nathan, of Wallyford, was delighted to reach the finish line, with the cyclists completing  kilometres over the eight hours.He added: ldquoThe aim was to get pound, and then we raised pound,.ldquoWe are really chuffed and ideally I would like to raise another pound so the cash is split into pound each.ldquoI think I was chuffed and on Saturday Hearts tweeted us and wished us luck.ldquoWe have got a few Hearts fans in the team so they were happy.To support the good cause, go to justgiving crowdfunding prestonathletic

title: paralympian-maria-lyle-takes-presenting-role-podcast
story: Maria Lyle is not hanging up her running spikes but has teamed up with journalist Gary Heatly to create This Ability Podcast.The monthly show sees the duo chat with a iety of guests about what it is like living with a disability and shines a light on some amazing achievements.Maria, who has spastic diplegic cerebral palsy, said: ldquoIt is something that I have never done before.ldquoGary approached me with the idea of doing it and highlighting how disabled people live their lives and to make it come across that a disability is not such a negative thing. It is something new and I have really enjoyed it and learning from Gary.The third episode of the podcast is being recorded this month.Each episode has been created during the coronavirus pandemic lockdown, with Gary, Maria and their guests in separate locations and speaking over Zoom.The first episode featured Maria, who lives in Dunbar, and Gary, who is based in Edinburgh, discussing their own personal experiences of living with cerebral palsy.Then, last month, the hosts spoke to actress Amy Conachan, who has appeared in more than  episodes of Hollyoaks as Courtney Campbell.Former Dunbar Grammar School pupil Maria said: ldquoShe was really nice and friendly. It was interesting to hear her story about acting and her journey to television, which has been very successful, and how she deals with her disability.Mariarsquos love of athletics began when she was at Dunbar Primary School, with her mum, Susan, taking a PE lesson.She previously said: ldquoOne day, when I was in about primary four, we had a multi-stage fitness bleep test-type thing to do.ldquoI wasnrsquot any good at anything and everything and I wasnrsquot looking forward to it at all ndash even though my mum was the teacher. Running at that stage usually ended with me falling over  per cent of the time and cutting my knees.ldquoBut I thought I would have a go and basically I was the last pupil standing at the end of the test.Since then, she has won medals at the Paralympics in Rio de Janeiro in  and two gold medals at the World Para Athletics Championships in Dubai last year, in the T m and m.The -year-old was due to represent Great Britain at the Paralympics in Tokyo this month before the international event was put back a year due to the coronavirus.She said it was nice to speak to people outside the sporting world about their lives and was looking forward to welcoming more guests onto the podcast.Gary, , who was previously editor of The SCRUM Magazine, praised Mariarsquos efforts on the new podcast. He said: ldquoShe has been absolutely brilliant.ldquoThe first podcast was just me and her having a chat about our own experiences. We are  years apart so we have dferent experiences.To listen to the podcast, go to play.acast s this-ability-podcast

title: plans-prestonpans-town-centre-revealed
story: The measures are being brought in by East Lothian Council under its Spaces for People scheme.It says that due to the limitations on space in the town, it is important that more spaces are introduced for people on foot, in wheelchairs and on bikes.A council spokesperson said: ldquoSupporting safe physical distancing for essential journeys and exercise is vitalwe are to suppress Covid-.ldquoIt will also improve opportunities for walking and cycling, creating environments that foster healthy and sustainable travel habits.Since last month, several new measures have already been introduced to Prestonpans, including a town-wide mph speed limit which also covers Cockenzie and Port Seton.Additional traffic calming measures were also brought in to allow the council to respond to requests for the use of public space, make it easier for people to cross the roadnecessary to maintain social distancing and support walking and cycling to school.Over the next few weeks, more measures will be introduced.On the south-east side of Prestonpans High Street, outside the Filling Station sandwich shop, the pavement will be widened and parking spaces for four cars removed the existing disabled parking space will remain.A three-metre-wide hard-surfaced temporary cycle route will be introduced adjacent to the north-western side of Edinburgh Road, between Prestonpans and Cockenzie.A temporary mph speed limit is also set to be introduced for Edinburgh Road, with regular traffic calming measures along the route.Measures to increase space for pedestrians on busy routes to school and at the school gates are being considered plans include widening pavements.More details on routes to school and the chance for members of the public to comment on them are available at bit.ly afajKcBefore the end of the year, the council hopes to explore the option of installing a public ebike hire station for eight bikes at Prestonpans Community Centre, Prestonpans High Street and in Cockenzie on Edinburgh Road and East Lorimer Place.Fiona OrsquoDonnell, ward councillor, said: ldquoI want to see businesses in our high streets able to operate safely.ldquoThese measures will help them do that with space for people to pass when queues are forming outside.ldquoFeeling they can shop and use other businesses safely will, I hope, encourage more people to use them, keep them open and protect jobs.ldquoThe mph limit will keep us all safer when out and about. I have already seen that it is making it easier for pedestrians to cross the road.ldquoI know it requires a change from drivers, and want to appeal to them to stick to the new limit.Brian Weddell, chair of Prestonpans Community Council, said: ldquoIrsquom very supportive [of the plans], particularly the slowing of traffic as wersquove been campaigning with Cockenzie and Port Seton and Longniddry Community Councils for a couple of years to get traffic speeds reduced entering the villages, so hopefully it will lead to that.He also expressed his support for the cycle path plans.

title: tranent-man-grabbed-womans-head-pushed-admonished
story: Michael Sneddon, of Lindores Drive, assaulted the woman by grabbing her head and squeezing her cheeks during an altercation at an address at the townrsquos Elphinstone Road.Sneddon also pushed the woman on the body, causing her to fall to the ground, on July  last year.The -year-old pleaded guilty at Edinburgh Sherf Court last year and sentence was deferred for him to be of good behaviour.Sneddon ed to the Capital court last Friday, where Sherf Donald Corke heard he had stayed out of trouble since his last court appearance.The sherf said he was content to admonish Sneddon on the charge.

title: retired-musselburgh-nurse-writes-book-caring-people-dementia
story: Dee Jenkins, , of Eskmills Road, said the main aim of the publication ndash I Remember Dementia ndash was to encourage carers of dementia patients.Born in Dublin in , Mrs Jenkins, who has lived in Musselburgh for  years, came to Scotland in  to enter a religious order, the Novitiate for the Sisters of La Sagesse, at Leuchie House, North Berwick. When it closed as a convent, the home became available for respite work for multiple sclerosis sufferers.Mrs Jenkins went on to train at the Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh from  to . She then joined the initial team of nurses at St Columbarsquos Hospice when it opened in .Mrs Jenkins left the order after  years and moved to Wales in  to take up a position as matron in a care home specialising in dementia care.She continued to care for people with dementia after ing to Scotland in , spending a decade in Edinburgh until she retired at the age of .Mrs Jenkins said: ldquoI worked in independent care homes as a manager, with the responsibility of training staff in this specialised field.ldquoI was inspired to write the book because people are becoming more aware of dementia and conscious of the dficulties it involves.ldquoI hope that my experiences might encourage those caring at home and provide some practical help and guidance.She added: ldquoIrsquom aware that Musselburgh as a town has shown a consciousness and willingness to provide supportive groups in this field of care, and hope this book may be of additional help and interest.The book is available on Amazon.

title: makeover-musselburghs-david-macbeth-moir-statue
story: The Old Musselburgh Club, supported by the Musselburgh Area Partnership and East Lothian Council, has reinstated the floodlighting and tidied up the statue of celebrated physician and writer David Macbeth Moir at the Mall.The project involved cutting back trees, repairing the floodlights as well as cleaning and repointing the main structure, and painting the railings.Club members paid tribute to Mike Foy and Glen Kane, of East Lothian Council, for their efforts with the pruning and electrical work involved at the monument which was erected in .Stuart Baxter, area partnership manager, and Iain Clark, area partnership chairman, supported by other area partnership members, also arranged for the base of the statue to be power washed, the main structure repointed and the surrounding railings painted at a cost of more than pound,. The area partnership allocates a budget from East Lothian Council to local projects.The Old Musselburgh Club marks the anniversary of the birth of Dr Macbeth Moir on the first Sunday in January each year with a church service and wreath-laying ceremony at the Mall.The  service will be held on Sunday, January , subject to restrictions as might apply in relation to Covid-.Born in the town in , Dr Macbeth Moir worked tirelessly as a doctor throughout his le and was Musselburghrsquos medical officer in  during the cholera epidemics which badly affected the local community.Club members are joined by descendants of his family Ian and Marion Moir from Edinburgh in remembrance of the man who was also a writer, adopting the Greek letter Delta as his pen name.Each year, a service in his memory takes place at a local church.Macbeth Moir had a family of , three of whom died under the age of four. A member of the Kirk Session at St Michaelrsquos Church, he was also a councillor. He was badly injured in accidents in  and again in , and his general health suffered. He died on July , , in Dumfries.He was a contributor of prose and verse to magazines, particularly to Blackwoodrsquos Magazine under his Delta pen name.There are several street names in the town which make reference to him, as well as the JD Wetherspoon pub The David Macbeth Moir.

title: new-signpost-celebrates-wallyfords-heritage
story: It points both walkers and cyclists to Prestongrange Mining Museum and the site of the Battle of Prestonpans, Queen Maryrsquos Mount at Carberry, the Pinkie Cleugh Battlefield Trail and Drt Path ndash some of which will feature in this yearrsquos East Lothian Online Heritage Festival.The signpost, located at the start of the Wallyford Industrial Estate road, was provided by Wallyford Community Council with funding from Musselburgh Area Partnership, which allocates a budget from East Lothian Council.The signpost cost pound, and its installation was pound.Alister Hadden, community council chairman, said: ldquoAs Wallyford continues to grow and expand, we thought it would be good to show residents who have come to make their home in the new housing estates some of our places of interest and rich heritage.ldquoThe signpost is also a little reminder to people who have lived in the village for longer.ldquoWallyford Community Council wishes to express its sincere thanks and appreciation to Musselburgh Area Partnership manager Stuart Baxter and chairman Iain Clark, along with the other members, for funding and supporting this project. Thanks also to Keith Scott and his East Lothian Council roads team for installing the sign for all to benefit from.ldquoWe are encouraged more to be out walking and cycling, and this will enable people to learn a little more about the history that surrounds us.The East Lothian Online Heritage Festival is held from August  to September .A spokesperson said: ldquoThis year we have decided to hold an online heritage festival in place of the traditional Archaeology  Local History Fortnight. It will be an exciting opportunity to celebrate East Lothianrsquos heritage in new ways, and to safely explore historic buildings and archaeological sites, without leaving home. We have got an exciting programme of over  events ndash from virtual guided tours, presentations and films to workshops, poetry, and music.For more information, visit www.johngraycentre.org about archaeology archaeolo gy-events east-lothian-online-heritage-festival

title: gullane-authors-new-book-satire-response-coronavirus-pandemic
story: It might sound rather familiar, but it is also the premise of Gullane author Charlie Laidlawrsquos latest book.Being Alert! was released earlier this month and follows in a long tradition of British satire, looking at how the Government has dealt with an existential threat that rapidly becomes a national crisis.Mr Laidlaw told the Courier: ldquoI think it is a book with a subject a lot of people will be writing about, looking at it from all dferent angles and the Governmentrsquos response to Covid- and whether it was appropriate or not.ldquoI think at some appropriate point the Government will be asked searching questions about its response.ldquoWhat I hope my book does is set out what those questions are from the point of view of ordinary people up and down the country who have been affected by Covid-, or had their lives ended by Covid-.Usually, publishing a book takes ldquomonths and months, with Mr Laidlaw, who is a marketing consultant, opting to self-publish his latest novel to ensure it was available.The -year-old said it had been ldquoa very dficult book to write as he attempted to strike the right balance between humour and anger on an emotive subject.Across the world, more than , people have died from coronavirus, with more than , deaths across Scotland linked to the virus.He said: ldquoI hope my book strikes a balance between humour, on a subject which is anything but funny, and anger, which I think a lot of people do feel.ldquoPutting those things together, I hope my book is part of a healing process as much as anything .Mr Laidlaw said a lot of people felt ldquohelpless or powerless throughout the coronavirus pandemic, with many questions unanswered.He felt there would come a time when those in power would be facing questions, such as why the country was not locked down sooner and why was there a lack of personal protective equipment , as well as how the country would react in the event of another pandemic.Mr Laidlaw has three previously published books ndash The Space Between Time, The Things We Learn When Wersquore Dead and Love Potions and Other Calamities ndash with a fth book set to be published in .

title: new-community-kitchen-set-tranent-help-feed-community
story: Farsquoside Community Kitchen will be operated by Duncan McBride and Joyce Thomson, who both cooked about , meals for local people during lockdown.Their work was initially part of the community resilience effort in Tranent, which was led by the townrsquos community council and overseen by its member Mike Falconer.Joyce started off delivering leaflets for the resilience team alongside her husband Andy.Ruth Davie, from Fundamental Foods, which set up the emergency food provision in Farsquoside and is overlooked by the Pennypit Trust, said she was looking for a chef to cook hot meals and Duncan, who works at The Sheep Heid Inn in Duddingston, Edinburgh, offered his services.Duncan then approached Joyce and Andy, his long-term friends, and soon got them involved.They then spent the next few months making thousands of meals from their base in Tranentrsquos East Lothian Co-operative Bowling Club, where Joyce works behind the bar, and used its kitchens to prepare the meals.They would be in the bowling club about five or six days a week making about  meals a day for those in need.Joyce said: ldquoIt was hard work to start with, we were making - meals a day but are now down to about .The pair then decided it was a good idea to carry this work on and set up a community kitchen.It is hoped that the new community kitchen will be based in the bowling club, although the venue is still to be confirmed.Duncan and Joyce will continue to work alongside the Pennypit Trust until they can support themselves independently.It is hoped that Farsquoside Community Kitchen will be open and al by next month, initially with social distancing in place.It is also a charity, with Joyce currently awaiting confirmation of the charity number.Joyce said that the community kitchen was set up to ldquohelp our most at need community in supplying very low cost meals, ensuring people continued to get the same quality of food they had under the resilience group.There is a community kitchen service already in operation in Haddington and the one in Tranent will be run along the same lines, but Joyce said Tranentrsquos would instead be open every day.She said she wanted to be able to provide good-quality, low-cost food to as many people as possible of all ages and backgrounds.There will be dferent menus on offer, such as those for breakfast and lunch, so prices will y but remain low.Joyce said: ldquoWe want to target everybody and have as many things on the menu as we can but still try and keep it simple.As well as food, she hopes the community kitchen will allow people to meet up and socialise with others.Some of the plans currently in the works include a dementia-friendly session and working with schoolchildren through the school hub, with deliveries of food still taking place once a week.A website is also being set up.Joyce hopes that she and Duncan will be able to give up their jobs at some point in the future and direct all of their time and effort into the community kitchen.She said: ldquoIrsquom hoping this takes off really well and will be busy enough every day.ldquoWersquore willing to put every hour into making it a success.ldquoI feel the community needs some sort of help like this.She thanked people who had donated so far, including local resident and bowler Ian James, who has donated a total of pound.Joyce said: ldquoThe amount of friends that have given donations over this time is unbelievable. Anything we need, people come through again and again, itrsquos totally amazing.She added that the overwhelming amount of support so far might be linked to her charity walks that she does every August alongside Brian Forbes. The -mile-long walks have raised about pound, for ious charities since they first took place.For more information on Farsquoside Community Kitchen, email f.dcomkit@gmail, call   or search for Farsquoside Community Kitchenon Facebook.

title: golf-star-catriona-matthew-visits-east-lothian-foodbank
story: Matthew, from North Berwick, visited the foodbank, on Tranentrsquos Civic Square, on August , the week before the competition took place.She brought some donations with her, and foodbank volunteer Barbara Edgar showed her around the foodbank.Matthew then helped make up a foodbank parcel for two adults in a household.She, alongside all of the foodbank volunteers, wore a mask and gloves while putting the food parcel together.The visit came after the foodbank was selected as the competitionrsquos official charity for this year, something foodbank director Candace Higgins said she was ldquoabsolutely delighted about and ldquoblown away by.On her visit, Matthew said: ldquoTo visit East Lothian Foodbank has been great actually.ldquoItrsquos just amazing seeing the volunteers and just seeing the work they did.ldquoBarbara showed me around and we made up a food pack for a couple for three days.ldquoBarbara, I must say though that I was very good at putting the little extras in all the time, so I think our bags were a little bit fuller perhaps than normal. Itrsquos quite humbling to see all the work that they do.ldquoItrsquos been fascinating to come and just see all the hard work ndash itrsquos run by volunteers ndash just to see all the work that they have been doing, especially the last four, five months during the pandemic.On the foodbank being selected as the Ladies Scottish Openrsquos official charity this year, she said: ldquoI think itrsquos great that big events like that thatrsquos going to be filmed worldwide, players coming from all over the world, it supports a local charity.Candace added: ldquoThe generosity of [tournament sponsors] Aberdeen Standard Investments, Catriona Matthew and everyone involved in the Ladies Scottish Open means we can continue doing vital work for the people of East Lothian.ldquoThis not only means we can continue to provide emergencyfood parcels to those in need but it will also allow us to expand and develop our community work to get to the root cause of food poverty in the county.As part of being the official charity, pound was donated for every birdie, pound per eagle and pound, for a hole in one across the whole competition.In total, pound, was donated.In celebration, the foodbank has also been running a social media campaign in line with #FeelGoodFood month.It was running the lsquoFeel Good Food Cuprsquo to find out the publicrsquos favourite comfort food, with the final a battle between tomato soup and rice pudding, with rice pudding victorious.Players also discussed their own feel good foods and a video of their answers can be watched at youtube watch vORcgdXdThAEast Lothian Foodbank was established in  to meet the needs of rising food poverty in East Lothian.

title: second-set-plans-approved-former-dunbar-coastguard-station
story: When Dunbar Coastguard swapped Lamer Street for Spott Road Industrial Estate last year, its former base was left empty. Now, the building overlooking the townrsquos East Beach could become a new home or holiday let.Judy Oxley was given planning permission to change the property into holiday accommodation, with the existing roof to be removed, the wall heads raised by one metre and a new roof put in place. The proposals did not, however, win universal approval.The local authorityrsquos planning department received six letters of objection to the plans.Grounds for concern included there being no parking for the home, as well as how noise from the building would ldquonegatively impact on neighbouring residential properties.Supporting the plans was Dunbar Community Council, which was keen to see the proposals given the go-ahead in order to ldquoregenerate the building and prevent its decay.It marks the second time in just a few weeks that Ms Oxley has been given planning permission to breathe new le into the building.East Lothian Councilrsquos planning officials had previously rejected a bid to turn the building into a bijou beachfront home. However, the local authorityrsquos Local Review Body overturned that decision on appeal when councillors said the proposal was better than leaving the building to fall into a state of disrepair.

title: 10-scottish-museums-back-business-visit-weekend
story: While we are still under the shadow of the virus, some things are beginning to come back, museums among them.The last few days has seen the reopening of both the National Museum of Scotland and Kelvingrove Museum.And while access is controlled and there are limitations on where you can go, after months in lockdown the chance to visit your favourite museumis surely to be welcomed.Herersquos  you might like to visit soon...And remember to wear that mask when yoursquore indoors.National Museum of Scotland, EdinburghReopened on Wednesday on reduced hours , the National Museum of Scotland is once again the perfect retreat for those seeking refuge from the temperamental Edinburgh weather. Pre-booked timed entry, mandatory face coverings and one-way routes are all now in operation as the museum tries totonormal. Entrance will be by the west door on Chambers Street.The museumrsquos reopening will be phased in. The entrance hall and level one are now open to visitors, but rooms with a high number of interactive displays, including the Imagine and Explore galleries, remain closed for the moment.Inevitably, the museum has had to postpone a number of special exhibitions, but it is home to Scotlandrsquos Precious Seas, an exhibition that explores the nationrsquos erse sea le and the effect climate change is having on our maritime environment. Itrsquos part of the Year of Coasts and Waters.Visit nms.ac.uk for more details and to book entryKelvingrove Museum, GlasgowPre-booking is also required for Kelvingrove which has reopened its doors to the public from am to pm daily. Tickets will be available up to two weeks in advance, with a maximum of six visitors for each booking, all from the same family. Entry will be timed and will allow visitors a two-hour slot. A one-way system has been introduced, but most of the main gallery spaces are open. Masks are required and there will be no catering facilities. But the toilets are open. Entrance is by the carpark side.That only leaves one question. Whatrsquos the first thing yoursquore going to visit when you get back in  Are you there for the ancient Egyptian artefacts or for a catch-up with the work of Charles Rennie Mackintosh PS, the Riverside Museum is reopening on August . Put it in your diary.For more information and to book tickets, visit glasgowmuseumsNational Museum of Flight, East FortuneBooking in advance for timed entry is required for the National Museum of Flight in East Fortune. But at least you donrsquot need to self-quarantine when you get off the planes here. Some buildings are still closed unfortunately, but the Concorde Experience, the Parachute Store and the civil and military aviation hangars are all open, as well as the shop and cafe. One-way routes are in use.And, of course, the airfield itself is open, which means you can have a look inside the planes ndash therersquos a Vulcan, a Comet and a BAC - ndash on display. No passports required.Visit nms.ac.uk national-museum-of-flightfor details and bookings.The McManus art gallery and museum, DundeeNamed Scotlandrsquos best visitor attraction not long before lockdown, the McManus reopened on Thursday and remains one of the most reliable boltholes in Dundee .Now open daily from Tuesday to Saturday, am to pm, there is no booking necessary and exhibitions are free. The cafeacute has reopened with social distancing measures and the shop will only allow four customers at a time. Entry numbers to the museum will also be limited so you might have to queue.Joseph McKenzies photography at the McManusStill, it will be worth it. To celebrate its reopening, two new exhibitions have just opened. Time and Tide: The Transformation of the Tay looks at the importance of the river in the continuing story of the city, while A Love Letter to Dundee: Joseph McKenzie Photographs - celebrates McKenziersquos evocative and nostalgic black and white images of Dundee as it once was.Visit mcmanusfor more detailsVA Dundee, DundeeStill a few days to wait. The VA reopens its doors on Thursday. Pre-booked timed entry is now required, and social distancing measures and one-way systems have been introduced. But on the plus side the Tatha restaurant will reopen, as will the shop. As the ground floor cafeacute has closed, the Tatha will also offer cafe and takeaway options.And along with the regular galleries, the museum reopens with a new exhibition celebrating the work of Mary Quant, the first international retrospective of the revolutionary fashion designer. As far as we know wearing a mini skirt is not a requirement for entrance. Just as well. Some of us donrsquot have the legs for it.If yoursquore really keen, of course, you could double up with a trip to the Dovecot Studios in Edinburgh where the current exhibition Mid-Century Modern also focuses on Quant along with Terence Conran.Visit vam.ac.uk dundee to book ticketsThe Stirling Smith Art Gallery and Museum, StirlingAh, The Smith. There is no museum in Scotland Irsquove spent more time in over the years. Having just reopened, it will now be accessible from Thursday to Sunday, am to pm, with a one-way system in operation. No booking necessary.The Stirling Story exhibition continues to occupy its main exhibition space. Artist and collector Thomas Stuart Smith bequeathed his own work and collection to the museum and it forms the heart of The Man Who Could Paint Anything: The Legacy of Thomas Stuart Smith in gallery two, supplemented by donations by subsequent benefactors. The work of Anne Redpath, William McTaggart and William Gillies are all represented in the exhibition. Paul Eamesrsquo The Power of Flight, meanwhile, continues in gallery one until September .Even better news. The Smith Cafe has also reopened. title: face-coverings-scotlands-schools-explained-guidance-say
story: The updated guidance comes off the back of new public health advice, including World Health Organisation guidelines.So who has to wear a mask  And is it mandatory Here, we detail out everything you need to know:Who should now wear coverings In secondary schools, adults and all pupils moving around the school, such as in corridors and communal areas, where physical distancing is dficult to maintain.However, like in shops and other indoor spaces where masks are mandatory, the Scottish Government accepts there will be some exceptions - including people with certain health conditions.When will this come into force The new guidance will apply from Monday, August .Will schools provide coverings Nicola Sturgeon said plans will be in place for schools to provide extra coverings, to ensure no-one goes without a covering who wants one.Concerns were raised over a lack of social distancing in schoolsWhat about on school transport The new guidance says that all children aged five and over should wear a face covering on dedicated school transport. This is now brought into line with the public transport guidance.What about primary school children With the exception of school buses as outlined above, the new guidance in schools only applies to secondary school pupils.Do they need to be worn in class While staff and students can continue to wear face coveringsthey wish to, they will not generally be necessary in the classroom.This is because there is greater scope for physical distancing and face coverings can have an impact on teaching.However it remains the case that where adults cannot keep m distance and are interacting face-to-face for a sustained period , face coverings should be wornCan a child be excluded for not wearing one It is expected that the guidance will state that pupils should not be excluded from schoolthey do not wish to wear a face covering.Can someone help my child with their covering Education Secretary John Swinney said:ldquoSchools will be asked to ensure children and young people have clear instructions on how to put on, remove, and store face coverings."Any staff member or pupil will still be able to wear a face covering when they wish to do so."John Swinney confirmed the new guidanceWhy is this being done Mr Swinney added:ldquoThere is increasing evidence that face coverings can provide some protection for the wearer as well as those around them."We also know that some pupils have found it very dficult to physically distance when moving around school, which could increase the risk of transmission of the virus."And on school transport, as on public transport, there can be mixing between dferent age groups."What  was said Mr Swinney said:ldquoWe want to continue to protect what we have achieved in suppressing the virus and re-opening schools, and to do the best for children in schools."Alongside this change to the wearing of face coverings, we need to reinforce the importance of maintaining high standards of cleaning, personal hand and respiratory hygiene and physical distancing, where possible."In situations where there is a local cluster, use of face coverings throughout the day may be required.ldquoThe position will be kept under review to ensure that our approach remains commensurate with the evidence and the levels of transmission in Scotland.

title: six-must-read-scottish-books-headed-tv-film
story: Over the years, a raft of titles ndash from Treasure Island to Trainspotting and morendash have been adapted for film and television.Here, weve pulled together a list of six Scottish books destined forour screens very soon. How many have you read Eleanor Oliphant Is Completely FineGail Honeymans smash debut novel has been optioned by Reese Witherspoons Hello Sunshine production company with a movie in the works.Set in contemporary Glasgow, Eleanor Oliphant Is Completely Fine is a warm, uplting and incredibly funny tale.Its indomitable eponymous heroine is a social misfit with a traumatic past.Witherspoon has a knack for finding stories that can make the jump from books. She produced the Oscar-nominated films, Gone Girl and Wild, as well as hit TV shows Big Little Lies and Little Fires Everywhere.ConvictionSpeaking of Witherspoon, she chose Conviction by Denise Mina as her Hello Sunshine Book Club pick last December.Although no film deal has been formally announced, theres a good chance that the actor and producer has an eye on bringing the whip-smart thriller ndash where a woman obsessed with true crime podcasts finds herself at the heart of a jet-setting murder mystery ndash to the screen.Jayd Johnson and Ford Kiernan in The Field of Blood - adapted from a Denise Mina novel. Picture: Mark Mainz BBCIn , Minas Paddy Meehan crime novels were adapted to become The Field of Blood, starring Jayd Johnson, David Morrissey and Peter Capaldi, which ran for two series. Her new novel, The Less Dead, is published by Harvill Secker, priced pound..A Dark MatterDoug Johnstonersquos domestic noir series centres on three generations of women ndash Jenny Skelf, her mother Dorothy and daughter Hannah ndash who run a family funeral director business with a sideline as private investigators in Edinburgh.A Dark Matter by Doug JohnstoneThe first novel, A Dark Matter, was published in January and has been optioned as a TV drama by Glasgow-based production company Blazing Grfin, while the second, The Big Chill, is published by Orenda, pricedpound.. Click here to read The Herald Magazine cover story with the author.Blood OrangeThis brilliant debut novel from Harriet Tyce has been optioned by World Productions ndash the makers of Line of Duty and Bodyguard ndash for development into a TV series.The gripping psychological thriller follows a high-flying criminal barrister taking on her first murder case at the same time as her personal le descends into chaos when an affair leads to dark obsession.The Edinburgh-born authors second book, The Lies You Told ndash like Blood Orange it is set in the world of criminal law ndash is published byWildfire, priced pound..Karen PirieITV is making a three-part crime drama based on The Distant Echo, the first in a series of cold case novels by Val McDermid. Set in St Andrews, DCI Karen Pirie is tasked with reopening an investigation into the murder of a teenage barmaid who has become the subject of a provocative true crime podcast.Val McDermids Wire in the Blood Picture: ITVKaren Pirie is another on the World Productions slate and is being adapted by Harlots writer Emer Kenny.A separate series of McDermids books were made into an ITV drama, Wire in the Blood, starring Robson Green as psychological profiler Dr Tony Hill in . Her latest DCI Karen Pirie thriller, Still Le, is published byLittle, Brown, priced pound.Ash MountainIf you were glued to the BBC thriller, The Cry, which starred Jenna Coleman as a young mother whose baby vanishes on a trip to Australia, then look out for Ash Mountain.The Cryrsquos author Helen FitzGeraldrsquos latest novel, published this month, is a deftly written and darkly funny portrait of small-town le as a woman s home to care for her gravely ill father.The TV rights have been snapped up by the new Melbourne-based offshoot of Glasgow production company Synchronicity Films, who also made The Cry. FitzGerald hails from Australia but has lived in Scotland for more than  years, so we can claim her as one of ours.

title: five-epic-munros-adventure-seeking-scots-attempt
story: With breath-taking views at the top, theres no wonder why adventure-seekers take to the climb for hours on end.But with almost  to pick from, it can be a dficult decision.Here, weve pulled together five Munros wed love to try:Braeriach, CairngormsThe Cairngorms are quite dferent to many of other Scottish mountain ranges. Although their summits are mostly rounded and sweeping, they combine to make a vast and wholly unique landscape.The mountains in the Cairngorms rise up out of the remnants of the ancient Caledonian pinewoods and are home to superb wildle and an array of dramatic corries. Braeriach is the third highest mountain in the British Isles and is protected by a long approach walk through a natural tree line.This Munro comes in at km and takes around - hours to complete.Braeriach, Aviemore, PH QTBraeriachBeinn Alligin, TorridonBeinn Alligin, meaning jewelled mountain, is one of three of the Torridon giants and well deserving of its name. This magnicent pair of munros has its own pinnacle ridge called the Horns of Alligin.Sitting on the seaward side of Torridon it has an unmatched viewpoint with glimpses of Skye and the sea to one side, and great peaks on the other side with the Horns providing a stunning foreground.The Munro is around km and takes around - hours.Beinn Alligin Torridon, Alligin, AchnasheenBuachaille Etive Mor, Glen CoeBuachaille Etive Mor is the head of Glen Coe and reigns supreme with its awe-inspiring pyramidal appearance. It is affectionately known by many climbers as the Bookie and, along with its twin Buachaille Etive Beag, are among the most photographed of the Scottish mountains and itrsquos easy to see why!This Munro is perfect for those who want a climb and some incredible views.It is around km and takes around - hours to complete.Aonach Eagach Ridge, A, Ballachulish PH HXLiathach, TorridonAnother of Torridonrsquos three mountains, Liathach is perhaps the finest of them all. Its higher Munro looks almost inaccessible from most directions and even the easiest ascent involves a bit of scrambling but itrsquos certainly worth the effort.Beyond this point the mountain becomes even more dramatic and offers the perfect path for thrill seekers to climb to the top. The hidden north side of the mountain is even more spectacular and is well worth exploring.Slightly longer than the other of Torridonrsquos mountains this walk is around .km and takes around - hours.Achnasheen, IV ETLiathachSgurr nan Gillean, SkyeMany regard Sgurr nan Gillean as being the finest peak on Skye and it is one of the more dficult on this list. Even the easiest ascent on the southeast ridge is a pretty tough scramble ndash the other two ridges venturing into the realm of rock climbing.It appears fairly dramatic from Sligachan but this actually conceals much of the mountainrsquos finest features and its only upon a closer visit to Coire a Bhasteir that the true scale and magnicence of the Pinnacle Ridge reveals this Munrorsquos true stature.This walk is around km and takes roughly  to  hours to complete.Skye, IV SW

title: angelina-jolie-interviewed-schoolgirl-bbc-newsround
story: Sofia Roper, an S student at North Berwick High School, was offered the opportunity to talk with the actress, and her -year-old co-star Brooklynn Prince, by BBC Newsround.Sofia, , said: ldquoIt was fun but it was also scary. It was overwhelming.The budding journalist was hired by the BBC after the news channel approached the schoolrsquos humanities department, asking to interview students about their highs and lows of lockdown.The Newsround crew were so impressed by the video submitted by Sofia that they offered her the chance to become a reporter and interview, via an online video call, the stars of new film The One And Only Ivan.Sofia, of High Street, East Linton, told the Courier that she did some research before talking to the film star.She said: ldquoI chose to do some research because itrsquos good to have a personal aspect to your questions.ldquoI practised interviewing with Ali Plumb [BBC Radio  film reporter] and it was much easier, I didnrsquot feel nervous at all talking to him, but then when I talked to Angelina I was very nervous. And I donrsquot understand why!Sofia joined  professional journalists on video conferencing  Zoom, all waiting for their slot to interview the Hollywood stars.Student Sofia Roper waits on Zoom to interview Angelina JolieShe said: ldquoIt was hard to hide that I was so nervous and imagine that I was talking to a completely normal person.ldquoAngelina and Brooklynn were friendly but they made me feel very scared, just because they had this kind of presence you could tell they were more confident.But Sofia said the experience had also made her more confident and was one she would be happy to have again.She said: ldquoOne of my old teachers was saying that I was a lot more confident now than I was when she taught me.Sofiarsquos proud mum, Soledad Garcia Ferrari, said: ldquoIt was all very unexpected. Shersquos been brilliant. She had to do lots of videos in preparation, she had to watch the film and comment on it.ldquoIt was so funny seeing all the little windows on Zoom, of all the reporters from all over the world.ldquoAnd the interview was two hours later than planned, so she was sitting by her computer for two hours waiting.ldquoBut Angelina was very friendly.Georgina Brownlee, one of Sofiarsquos teachers in the humanities department, said: ldquoThe BBC got in touch during lockdown to ask for some clips of pupil lsquolockdown highs and lowsrsquo and a number of our junior pupils participated by entering a personal -second video clip, broadcast on Newsround during lockdown.ldquoFrom there, the BBC editor got in touch to ask Sofia to do a further interview, this time on the new Disney film The One and Only Ivan, starring Angelina Jolie.ldquoThe humanities faculty are delighted with Sofiarsquos impressive performance during her inaugural role as a BBC reporter she did a superb job interviewing a Hollywood megastar.ldquoSofia is a dedicated student and we will continue to facilitate the links and opportunities that have emerged from the BBC for all of our pupils.As for Sofiarsquos next journalist experience  The junior reporter said shersquod like to chat with a YouTuber.She said: ldquoI like YouTubers because they donrsquot have a script.ldquoYou donrsquot have to interview them to know what kind of person they are. Theyrsquore funny and entertaining.ldquoI like Georgia Productions ndash shersquos my favourite.The interview is at bbc newsround

title: coronavirus-maskne-seven-ways-look-skin-wearing-masks
story: However, people wearing face coverings every day have been noticing that they have started to break out in acne, rashes and skin irritations.Have you had more breakouts since you started wearing a mask We have spoken to Dermalogica skin care expert and beautician Ashley Richards to find out why this happens and how you can protect your skin.What is ldquomaskne Maskne occurs when sweat, oil and bacteria are trapped on your skin while wearing a mask, creating the perfect breeding ground for breakouts.What causes it Maskne is caused by friction, rubbing, and occlusion of the skin by outside forces.Wearing a mask can trap dirt, oil, swear and humidity around the skin.Friction and irritation from the mask pushes bacteria into the skin, which creates micro-tears, and allows the bacteria and dirt to enter the skin more easily.This will lead to blackheads and whiteheads along the bridge of your nose, cheeks and chin. Masks can trigger ious types of skin irritationsand redness .There isnrsquot a prevention for maskne, as we need to continue wearing our masks, but there are ways that you can help combat the issues.Skin Care routineIf you want to combat the impact of maskne then having a good skincare routine is essential.It is just as important to cleanse your skin before wearing a mask as it is to cleanse after wearing a mask.To help your skin heal, Ashley would recommend using a squalane or balm cleanser so help remove make-up, dirt and debris.However,you are experiencing chapped, irritated skin or suffer from sensitivity then a gel based cleanseradvised.Dermalogicarsquos UltraCalming Cleanser helps to calm and cool sensitised irritated skin.ExfoliatingExfoliating is key to clear clogged pores and remove dead skin cells which will help reduce the impact of maskne.There are thousands of dferent types of exfoliators available from chemical, physical and masks but it is always important to follow the recommended application and how often you should use the product.Over-exfoliating your skin can compromise your skins barrier , damage the skins capillaries and dehydrate the skin.Ingredients such as glycolic acid, lactic acid and salicylic acid are great exfoliating athelping fight breakouts.Spot treatmentsUsing targeted spot treatments with ingredients such as salicylic acid and benzoyl peroxide will help remove dead skin cells and decongest pores.Hyaluronic AcidsHyaluronic acid can hold , times its weight in water - so it is like a magnet for moisture.Using hyaluronic acid regularly will leave the skin feeling super-soft, radiant and reduce the appearance of fine lines and wrinkles.Hyaluronic acid has antibacterial properties meaning it will help soothe and protect chapped, irritated skin.FoundationsOpt for tinted moisturisers rather than a heavy foundation or go bare faced to help cause less clogging in your pores - but donrsquot forget your SPF!MoisturisersHeavier moisturisers will sit on the skin for longer due to the humidity of wearing the mask which can cause further clogging and irritation of the skin.However, donrsquot want to stop using a moisturiser all together as our skin still requires hydration and moisture.Instead try using a light and soothing moisturise such as Charlotte Tilburyrsquos Magic Cream light.Chapped SkinFor those suffering from chapped skin try using a physical barrier cream such as Dermalogicarsquos Barrier Repair.Barrier Repair shields against environmental pollution and helps forty sensitive skin with a damaged barrier.

title: musselburgh-man-kevin-yip-admonished-breaching-asbo
story: Kevin Yip was ordered not to have more than two visitors to his home at Newbigging when the ASBO was imposed on him at Edinburgh Sherf Court in May .The order was handed out following several complaints of noise and anti-social behaviour from Yip and visitors to the property.But the -year-old broke the order on February  this year when police officers found he had more than two people inside the flat.Yip appeared at the Capital court last Tuesday, where Sherf John Cook heard he had not been in any more trouble since and he was admonished on the complaint.Not guilty pleas to allegations of possession of diazepam and behaving aggressively towards police officers on the same date were accepted by the Crown.

title: housing-plan-musselburgh-poundland-poundstretcher-post-office-site
story: An outline plan has been drawn up for the land and building that houses Poundstretcher, Poundland and the Post Office, which is currently up for sale.Edinburgh-based Scarlett Land and Development is inviting offers for the ldquoprime location with ldquoconsiderable redevelopment potential on behalf of the owner, who has not been named.Situated on the corner of Dalrymple Loan and High Street, an outline plan for  residential properties plus two commercial units has been drawn up for the site, subject to planning permission.Scarlett Land and Development stated: ldquoThe site lies in the defined town centre, adjacent to the Musselburgh Conservation Area and in close proximity to listed buildings.ldquoPlanning permission will be required for any redevelopment proposal and, whilst not allocated for any specic use within the East Lothian Local Development Plan, it is likely that a mixed use development of ground floor commercial with residential use above will be acceptable, subject to a high-quality scheme respecting the setting of the listed buildings, the character and appearance of the adjacent conservation area and the scale of buildings in the surrounding area.Architects have drawn up an outline scheme comprising of  residential units plus two commercial units at ground level fronting High Street. The housing is listed as one, two and three-bedroom properties, plus two commercial units of  and  sq.m.A spokesperson for Poundland said: ldquoWe rent the store from the landlord and so the ownership is not really our concern. But we love being in Musselburgh and are proud to be part of the townrsquos retail community.A Post Office spokesperson said: ldquoThe premises where Musselburgh Post Office is based are up for sale. Poundstretcher is the company that operates this Post Office. We have not received any resignation at this stage, so it is business as usual at this Post Office.Poundstretcher had not responded at the time of going to press.Colin Beattie, Musselburgh MSP, said: ldquolsquoAny business being put up for sale comes at a cost to the community, as with the loss of a local business comes a loss of jobs and services to the area.ldquoWhile we come out of the Covid- pandemic, we need businesses as we start to re-energise our economy. Though we also need more houses to be built locally, I would hope that these are not replacing valuable businesses locally ndash a decision which is permanent and negatively affects the lives of anyone employed there.ldquoI hope that suitable thought goes into this proposal and that the iniduals that this would affect are given the utmost consideration.ldquoAs always, I hope that the highest attention is given to the views of those who live in the community, as their opinions are what really matter in planning decisions.Kenny MacAskill, East Lothian MP, said: ldquoDevelopment is needed but must be appropriate for a busy location and central site.Musselburgh Conservation Society said it would reserve its position until members saw what was being proposed.Musselburgh resident and Green campaigner Jason Rose, via social media, mooted the idea of the community owning the site and asked members of the public what they would like to see.One post stated: ldquoA proper covered market with independent fishmongers, grocers and butchers, plus other local producers and space for outdoor stalls too.ldquoWhat is needed is parking. No parking, limited shoppers, added a member of the public.Another said: ldquoSomething for the creative industry would be good. Small units at reasonable rents, photography studio with workshop space, sound recording studio, rehearsal spaces for bands musicians.One post added: ldquoCould be nice to have a proper supermarket right on High St again.ldquoMy granny was forever complaining that Tesco was too far and it is quite a walk.

title: east-lothian-peeps-past-august-25-28-1995-1970-1920
story: A POTENTIALLY fatal craze in Dunbar was highlighted in the East Lothian Courier on August , .Children as young as  are risking their lives by ing ft into Dunbar harbour.The fine summer weather has enticed groups of youngsters to put on their swimming trunks and leap into the water at the harbour entrance.And warnings that their antics could be fatal have only moved the boys on to even more dangerous jumps into the rocky sea near the ruined castle.Dunbar community policeman PC David Munro said that the craze had been going on for several weeks and the dozen-strong group ldquodid not seem to appreciate the dangers.ldquoApart from the diesel, oil and other chemicals that are floating on the surface, the kids are also at risk from the boats that are coming in and out, he said.ldquoThey could easily fall on to rocks belowthey slipped or lost their footing and it is also worrying that younger children are coming along and want to imitate the older ones.A NEW school opened in Haddington, reported The Haddingtonshire Courier of August , .Haddingtonrsquos new school ndash Kingrsquos Meadow Primary School ndash opened its doors to pupils for the first time on Monday.The school, which cost about pound, to build, can accommodate  pupils.Built by James Harrison and CoLtd., Edinburgh, it was designed by Mr Colin Stewart, a Haddington man employed as an architect by the firm. It has four basic teaching units, each comprising four classrooms and toilets, which are linked together by corridors.The headmaster of Kingrsquos Meadow is Mr R. C. Murdie, who has been employed by the local education authority for the past seven years.A FISHERMANrsquoS tragic death at Port Seton Harbour was reported in The Haddingtonshire Courier of August , .On Wednesday, about  a.m., while preparing to go to his boat which lay off the middle pier at Port Seton harbour, Mr John Harkess fell into the water.He was immediately noticed and, within a very few minutes, was brought to the cement slope on which the fish sales are held.An attempt was made to resuscitate Harkess, who was a man of about  years of age, but unsuccessfully.Medical aid was quickly forthcoming. title: dave-berry-column-gosford-house-magnificent-secret
story: Lennoxlove is a modied peel tower Winton has architectural echoes of a fortication. But none has the Italianate opulence of Gosford.Behind two miles of high walls, Grade lsquoArsquo magnicence is hidden from public view.The estate the wall encloses was held by many Scots names before, being bought by the Wedderburns of Inveresk. They enclosed fields and laid out avenues of trees, evident on Royrsquos map of .In , it all passed to the seventh Earl of Wemyss, who had already added Amisfield, Morham and Abbey Mill to his extensive Fe estates.He gave the brilliant Robert Adam his last great commission, replacing an existing house. The surrounding parkland was redesigned by James Ramsey. Not completed until , both earl and successors disliked the result. Not only did they not move in, but the eighth earl even demolished both wings.In , the th earl commissioned replacement wings from William Young to house his collection of Italian and Dutch masters. Finally, in , the family moved in.The neoclassical result blends with Adamrsquos original concept and ranks among Scotlandrsquos grandest stately homes. The south wing became the family residence, with the entrance relocated here. A three-storey-high marble entrance hall carries two sweeping staircases up to the spacious gallery on the first floor.Following the th earlrsquos death in , the house was used as a hotel until being requisitioned by the army in , to be used as an officersrsquo mess for a large camp in the park.Unfortunately, the central block burned during a social event and suffered temporary roofing for years until the th earl, moved in in , provided a proper re-roofing in . He also refurbished the extensive ponds and permitted the first public tours, still limited to a half-dozen days around Easter and in August.The th earl was very active in civic le, holding many senior appointments in Scotland, including Lord Lieutenant for East Lothian and chairman and then president of the National Trust for Scotland between  and . He lived a long le to age , whereupon the titles passed to the present th earl. Despite remaining the family seat, the th earlrsquos business interests and those of his second we means they live in Gloucestershire and the house is again unoccupied ndash as was the case for over half its existence.

title: iain-gray-msp-column-rediscover-solidarity-lockdown
story: However, recess never actually happened ndash Parliament has continued to meet throughout the summer to deal with Covid- and related issues.It is a moment to pause and reflect, though. Over the summer, we have seen lockdown partially eased but that is not proving easy.Cases are rising again. The Government has had to slow down its lsquoroute maprsquo to opening society up, and that has led to what seem like contradictions.Pubs and restaurants open, but gyms and swimming pools closed young adults wearing face coverings in supermarkets but not in schools a list of lsquoquarantinersquo countries which changes almost daily.If this is the lsquonew normalrsquo, then in some ways it is proving harder than everyone being locked down. We all applauded the NHS as it coped so well with the virus peak, but many constituents are becoming frustrated at how long it is taking to open up for their routine treatments or operations.Only weeks ago we were hailing Scotland as doing so much better than England.It turns out the pandemic numbers were just being counted dferently, and local lockdowns around Manchester were followed by Annan and Aberdeen. Scottish people have proven just as likely to flock to the beach or ill-advised house parties as anyone .Everyonersquos patience is being tested now. We can do this, though. Remember the community spirit which saw resilience groups form in all of our towns and villages  Remember clapping for the NHS and social care workers  Remember looking out for vulnerable neighbours and friends  It is time to rediscover that solidarity and keep on looking out for, and looking after, each other.

title: coronavirus-scotland-book-covid-test-testing-centres
story: The First Minister suggests some Scots have had trouble trying to book coronavirus tests over the weekend due to a "major spike" in demand, which resulted in technical issues.Butyou are experiencing symptoms, how do you get a test  Heres everything you need to know.If you think you are experiencing symptoms of coronavirus, you should take a test. A test should be taken within the first three days of showing symptoms, but testing is effective until day five.You wonrsquot normally be tested after day  unless itrsquos for a specic reason. This will be agreed on a case-by-case basis.Anyone with symptoms of coronavirus should be tested. You can book a test for either yourself,someone you care for ora child in your care.Key workers, and anyone in their household with symptoms, can access testing through their employer in the first instance and will be given priority.For more information on key worker priority, visit NHS Inform.Currently, there are testing sites at Glasgow, Edinburgh, Aberdeen and Prestwick airports, and in Perth and Inverness at the University of the Highlands and Islands campuses.There are also home testing kits available, which are delivered and collected by Amazon and Royal Mail. You can order one here.There are several ways to get tested for Covid- in Scotland.You can have a home testing kit delivered to your home, or attend one of the testing sites.To book a test, you are asked to complete a self-help guide, which can be found online, to checkyou are eligible. If you cant access the form online, you can callthe coronavirus helpline on   .The coronavirus tests involves taking a swab of the inside of your nose and the back of your throat. This is done using a long cotton bud.According to NHS Inform, results are issued to whoever booked the test and are fed back into public health records.They are sent by text to your mobile phone and should be with you within  hours.

title: hollies-day-centre-musselburgh-reopen-monday
story: Liz Shannon, manager, said the reopening of the High Street facility, which offers activities for older people as well as a public cafe, would be ldquoin a limited capacity to allow for social distancing.The public cafe and hairdresser will be back in business on Monday, with hopes that other activities, such as the lunch club, might start again next month.Ms Shannon said: ldquoMajor work has been carried out over the lockdown period, including a deep clean of the building.ldquoWe are sorry but, due to the current pandemic, a number of changes have had to be put in place for customersrsquo and staff safety, and to comply with Government health and safety guidelines. As before, we are a cash-only facility.The cafe will reopen in the hall am-pm, Monday to Wednesday.Ms Shannon said: ldquoWe will see how it will work and,it works well, we can extend our days back to five.ldquoThere will be a limited number of customers able to attend, around , and the time in the cafe limited to  minutes per person. Entry will be by the black gate from High Street into the hall. A track and trace system will be in place and customers will be required to leave their name and contact telephone number, have their hands sanitised and wear a face covering until seated. All must comply with these conditions or entry will be prohibited. A limited menu will be provided at this stage.The hairdresser at the day centre will also reopen by appointment, following the same days, times and entry system.Ms Shannon said: ldquoCustomers for the hairdresser will have to keep a mask on at all times and use the stair lt to the first floor. They will be required to bring their own refreshments as no tea or coffee will be provided.She stressed both cafe and hairdresser customers would leave from the front door of the building.Ms Shannon paid tribute to Musselburgh-based RR Roofing  Building Ltd, which came to the rescue last week to carry out repairs on a leaky roof at the centre which, it had been feared, could have been a major setback to the reopening.

title: 60-events-offer-east-lothian-online-heritage-festival
story: East Lothian Online Heritage Festival boasts events ranging from virtual guided tours and presentations to films and workshops.The festival, on until September , is running in place of the traditional Archaeology and Local History Fortnight, which has been postponed.Events include The Big Glassworks Dig at Port Seton on September  and . Digs will be broadcast live so everyone can follow any discoveries from the old glassworks as they are uncovered.Battlefield events commemorating the Battles of Dunbar, Pinkie Cleugh and Prestonpans, including live footage from the commemoration ceremonies, will take place, as well as online exhibitions and films related to the Year of Coast and Waters, using historic images and oral histories from the archives.Councillor Norman Hampshire, cabinet spokesman for the environment, said: ldquoIrsquom delighted our archaeology service has developed this alternative way of celebrating East Lothianrsquos rich heritage and history.ldquoWith a vast array of historic buildings and sites to explore virtually through more than  events, Irsquod encourage people to participate.On Saturday, events include the chance to join the Salt of the Earth project for a day of celebration of the heritage of the Prestonpans, Cockenzie and Port Seton, Longniddry and Gosford areas.There is the chance to take a virtual walk around Tranentrsquos historic burgh boundary and a guided heritage walk over, under and around seven bridges over the Esk in Musselburgh.Also on Saturday, Graeme Cavers, from AOC Archaeology, will give a presentation about how LiDAR was used to map the archaeology of the Lammermuirs. A traditional skills festival looking at everything from stone carving and pottery to herb foraging and plaster casting takes place.A short film based on interviews with fishermen from Cockenzie and Port Seton will be shown, while there is also a chance to find out how to build your own lsquoTrace Italiennersquo fort.On Sunday, Nicola Wright will tell stories inspired by coast, water and archaeology, while a childrenrsquos workshop takes place in Amisfield Walled Garden, near Haddington. Liz Curtis shares stories behind the place names of East Lothian and there is a presentation about John Muirrsquos home in Dunbar.Monday starts with a look at the history of Dunbar, which is marking  years since the town was granted its charter.Gullane and Dirleton History Society hosts a virtual guided walk of the Gullane end of the old branch railway line.The following day, a film looking at the Cousland Smiddy is shown, while there is a slideshow of some of the historic re-enactment events that Catching the Past has been involved in.Historian David Affleck explores the history of Whittingehame Estate, while Kate Campbell has written a collection of poetry inspired by the area around Whiteadder Reservoir.On Wednesday, a short slideshow looks at the history of county ports and harbours and Courier columnist Tim Porteus tells three East Lothian tales.For more information, go to johngraycentre.org

title: first-full-east-lothian-council-meeting-since-lockdown-sees-local-heroes-praised
story: A momentrsquos silence was held for those people who died from Covid- and their families, as councillors paid tribute to the community efforts which had come to the fore during the crisis.Councillor Fiona Dugdale summed up the praise from elected members during the virtual meeting, held online, by saying: ldquoI do not think there are enough words to thank our staff and the amazing army of volunteers who stepped up in the midst of a national health crisis not knowing how it would affect or its impact on their own families.ldquoThe depth of gratitude is immense to all our staff and all our volunteers across the county,ldquoThey are all our local heroes at the heart of our communities.And Provost John McMillan told the committee: ldquoA hero is an ordinary person who does extraordinary things and all those ordinary people who stepped up did extraordinary things.The council meeting heard that a snapshot of services provided by the council and its partners the week before community resilience teams stood down showed , people who were shielding were in contact with support teams and , free school meals and lunch packs were delivered to children.The six childrenrsquos hubs which provided care for the families of key workers and vulnerable children at its peak in June saw  young people attend and  teaching staff working in them.Councillor Willie Innes, council leader, said: ldquoRight across the county, people have been magnicent.ldquoI am proud of our council staff, who have worked above and beyond to ensure the safety and wellbeing of communities.And Councillor Jim Goodfellow, spokesperson for community wellbeing, said: ldquoThe magnicent numbers of volunteers who have come forward has demonstrated what this county is all about.Councillor Fiona OrsquoDonnell also added her thanks to staff and volunteers, pointing to work in her Preston SetonGosford ward, from community councils to third sector and volunteers.And fellow ward councillor Lachlan Bruce said that too many people to name had made remarkable efforts to support the communities.Mr Bruce said: ldquoWe are incredibly lucky in this county and it has highlighted how great this county is, with communities coming together, all doing amazing work.Councillor Shamin Akhtar, education spokesperson, passed on her thanks to parents and carers for their work.And Councillor Craig Hoy also paid tribute to shop workers who kept services open.He said: ldquoLocal shops, petrol stations and small businesses, as well as large supermarkets and small stores, all stayed open to support their communities throughout and should be thanked.Councillor Stuart Currie called for a moment of silence to be held, saying: ldquoIt is right to remember the people who are not going to see the other side of this pandemic and their families.The council closed the meeting with a moment of silent reflection in tribute.

title: haddington-residents-yard-sale-helps-support-community-kitchen
story: Residents of Burnside, Clerkington Road and Fairway came together to do their bit for Our Community Kitchen.The lsquoyard salersquo collected pound for the group, which meets in Haddington Bowling Club.Elaine Gale, who founded Our Community Kitchen, was delighted with the success of the event at the beginning of the month.She said: ldquoIt is just so lovely.ldquo[Support from the community] has been enormous really and the amount and sheer scale of support we have had locally for what we are doing is absolutely incredible.The money raised will go towards the general running costs of the group, which, pre-coronavirus, was serving up lunches to people who were suffering from isolation in the bowling club.However, with social gatherings ruled out, the group decided to continue preparing meals but instead take them to peoplersquos homes.Meals such as chicken and leek pie and stovies have been delivered to homes throughout Haddington during the lockdown period.That will be scaled back slightly as restrictions are eased but Elaine said they were still delivering more than  meals a week to people in need.Volunteers have also been taking the time to phone vulnerable members of the community to check they are alright.The scheme will continue and Elaine said: ldquoAs a charity, we are committed to looking after the community.ldquoThat is part of what we will be doing going forward thatrsquos not going to stop.ldquoWe recognise people will still need us.

title: lyn-jardine-hopes-snps-east-lothian-candidate-scottish-parliament-election-2021
story: Lyn Jardine, a former chair of Womenrsquos Aid East and Midlothian, has joined Dunbar and East Linton Councillor Paul McLennan, and Iain Whyte, office manager for Paul Wheelhouse, South of title: east-lothian-council-astro-turf-ban
story: The schoolrsquos popular astroturf pitch ndash used primarily for hockey but also other activities ndash proved too big a draw for youngsters as classes ed full-time and it was closed to students at breaks and lunchtime.Parents urged the school to reconsider the decision after youngsters came home claiming they had been told the risk of them touching goal posts ndash and potentially creating a higher risk of spreading Covid- ndash was too great.And the school said that it would introduce a system which would allow children access to the pitch one day a week on a year by year basis.As classes ed in full last Monday, it is understood staff became concerned at the number of students gathering together on the astroturf pitch from dferent years.However, the decision to ban children from the pitch left some parents bemused.One mum took to social media, saying: ldquoSurely the kids can touch door frames and bins and walls in all the other outdoor areas ndash why are the goal posts so scary Another added: ldquoI understand they are under pressure and trying to keep kids and adults safe but surely this isnrsquot necessary One mum received a reply from the schoolrsquos PE department pledging to look into a way more supervision could be given to the pitch to allow youngsters to use it in a ldquosafe and sensible manner.Each year group has now been allowed to use the astroturf one day a week.An East Lothian Council spokesperson said: ldquoThe astroturf is a popular facility at North Berwick High School.ldquoIn line with official guidance, the school is discouraging large groups from congregating and the space was being used by a number of dferent year groups at the same time.ldquoIt was closed to young people for two days to allow the staff team to put in place a schedule that will allow each year group to use it one day a week with staff supervision and cleaning in place.ldquoThis is especially important as it is also used for PE. North Berwick High School, like all our schools, is working hard to understand and apply guidance on theto our buildings.ldquoWhere we can identy better ways of working we are doing so. This is one example.

title: preston-lodge-high-school-headteacher-gavin-clark-apologises-pupils-soaked
story: Initial guidelines introduced by the school meant pupils were told to go outside at lunchtime and during breaks despite the downpours, with claims they were only allowed inside to use the toilets. Some pupils said they ed home wearing jackets and hoodies still soaked from being out in the rain earlier in the day.Afterwards, Mr Clark sent a letter to families, telling them: ldquoWe very much regret the fact that many of our students got wet at break, lunch and or in PE lessons on Monday and we have worked hard over the last  hours to reassure a number of parents carers who raised understandable concerns.ldquoWe were perhaps working too hard to meet national guidance, and on this occasion our desire to maximise student time outside and prevent large gatherings of students indoors, as per Government advice, negatively impacted on student wellbeing.And in the schoolrsquos PLus newsletter, he said: ldquoWe have had a really good week at Preston Lodge, after a dficult Monday. Heavy rain, combined with a challenging set of Government guidelines, led to many students getting wet on that day, but I am glad to say that today our new approach to indoor breaks worked well and, other than those who chose to go outside, everyone stayed dry!An East Lothian Council spokesperson said: ldquoAll schools are working hard to implement guidance to provide a safeto buildings. In particular, secondary schools have to minimise large gatherings within indoor spaces and encourage small groups with physical distancing outwith.ldquoOur schools have been clear to all parents that children and young people should come to school dressed for the weather.ldquoTheto school this year has been challenging and we, and our schools, are working hard to understand and apply guidance.
